720b6bfa9f52478587ea1a9fa0c60903.title: VIPR I-BPA for Incident Base Unit for Region 5 - Pacific Southwest Region ONLY
720b6bfa9f52478587ea1a9fa0c60903.insights:
1. Top Level Summary:
The USDA Forest Service West Zone ESB Region 5 is soliciting quotes for Incident Base Units specifically for the Pacific Southwest Region (Region 5). These units will support local to nationwide fire suppression, all-hazard incidents, and prescribed fire projects. Contractors must provide fully equipped, staffed, and managed units meeting or exceeding specifications, including transportation and lodging. The contract supports multiple agencies optionally and will be competitively awarded as multiple preseason Incident Blanket Purchase Agreements (I-BPAs), primarily set aside for small businesses. The solicitation and all communications will be conducted electronically via the Virtual Incident Procurement (VIPR) system.

2. Timeline to Accomplish Requirements:
- Pre-solicitation Preparation: Ensure all vendor registrations (SAM, UEI, Login.gov, VIPR account) are complete – 2 to 4 weeks before solicitation release.
- Solicitation Release & Quote Submission: Once RFQ is issued via VIPR, vendors submit electronic quotes – typical RFQ response period 2 to 4 weeks.
- Evaluation and Award: USFS evaluates quotes, awards multiple I-BPAs prior to fire season – approximately 4 to 6 weeks after quote deadline.
- Contract Period: Incident Base Units activated as needed throughout the fire season and all-hazard incident response window, typically spanning spring through fall (6 to 9 months).
- Annual Review & On-Ramping: Contracting Officer annual review for adding resources – occurs once per year post initial award.

3. Estimated Valuation of the Contract:
- The solicitation pricing is based on 16-hour daily shifts with rates covering all personnel, equipment, lodging, and transportation.
- While exact quantities are not provided, Region 5 covers a large fire-prone area; typical Incident Base Unit contracts may range from $500,000 to $2,000,000+ annually depending on unit size and incident demand.
- Multiple awards indicate aggregate contract valuation could exceed several million dollars regionally.

4. Action Plan with Estimated Man-Hours:
a) Pre-solicitation phase (20-40 hours):
   - Register and verify SAM, UEI, Login.gov, and VIPR accounts (10-15 hours)
   - Review solicitation once released, analyze Section D.2 equipment/personnel specs (10-15 hours)
   - Prepare pricing and technical quote documents (10 hours)

b) Quote Submission phase (10-15 hours):
   - Populate VIPR system with required data and upload documentation (5-8 hours)
   - Respond to any clarifications or negotiations (5-7 hours)

c) Mobilization phase post-award (40-80 hours):
   - Procure/prepare equipment and materials (20-30 hours)
   - Recruit, train, and certify personnel to meet contract specs (20-40 hours)
   - Arrange logistics: transportation schedules, lodging, dispatch coordination (10-15 hours)

d) Incident Support phase (variable; example estimate for 6-month fire season):
   - Daily operation management and personnel supervision (~2-4 hours daily per manager)
   - Maintenance and resupply (~4-8 hours weekly)
   - Estimated total for 6 months (180 days): 360-720 hours for management personnel

e) Reporting and Contract Compliance (20-40 hours):
   - Incident documentation and invoicing (10-20 hours)
   - Performance review and updates for annual on-ramping consideration (10-20 hours)

Overall, initial setup and quote preparation require approximately 60-90 man-hours, with ongoing operational man-hours dependent on incident frequency and contract utilization.

- Participation in Region 5 contracts could serve as a foothold for future bids in other regions or multi-region contracts.

Opportunities exist to expand government contracting scope and leverage multi-agency missions, but competition, socioeconomic set-asides, and logistical challenges present notable threats to bid success. Bridger should weigh these factors carefully when preparing its bid strategy.
